intro: Brassica monensis var. cheiranthifolia, commonly known as the Indian mustard or wild mustard, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring lobed leaves and yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its seeds are small, yellowish, and contain high levels of glucosinolates, which contribute to its characteristic taste and potential health benefits. It is often found in disturbed soils and thrives in temperate climates.
